question.title: How to parse JSON in Java
question.body:
I have the following JSON text. How can I parse it to get the values of pageName, pagePic, post_id, etc.?

{
  "pageInfo": {
    "pageName": "abc",
    "pagePic": "http://example.com/content.jpg"
  },
  "posts": [
    {
      "post_id": "123456789012_123456789012",
      "actor_id": "1234567890",
      "picOfPersonWhoPosted": "http://example.com/photo.jpg",
      "nameOfPersonWhoPosted": "Jane Doe",
      "message": "Sounds cool. Can't wait to see it!",
      "likesCount": "2",
      "comments": [],
      "timeOfPost": "1234567890"
    }
  ]
}

answers.body:
Using common JSON Libraries in Java:

Jackson: Jackson is a very popular, high-performance library. It's versatile and supports various JSON processing tasks, including streaming, data binding (mapping JSON to Java objects), and tree model processing. It's widely used and well-documented.

import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper;

ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();
String jsonString = "{\"name\":\"John\", \"age\":30}";

try {
    MyObject myObject = objectMapper.readValue(jsonString, MyObject.class); // Data Binding
    System.out.println(myObject.getName()); // Accessing data
} catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}

// Example MyObject class (for data binding)
public class MyObject {
    private String name;
    private int age;
    // Getters and setters...
    public String getName() { return name;}
    public void setName(String name) { this.name = name;}
    public int getAge() { return age;}
    public void setAge(int age) { this.age = age;}
}

Gson (Google Gson): Gson is another widely used library known for its simplicity and ease of use. It's particularly good for data binding.

import com.google.gson.Gson;

Gson gson = new Gson();
String jsonString = "{\"name\":\"John\", \"age\":30}";

MyObject myObject = gson.fromJson(jsonString, MyObject.class);
System.out.println(myObject.getName());

JSON-java (org.json): This is a simpler, lightweight library that's often included with Android. It's good for basic JSON parsing and doesn't require as many dependencies as Jackson or Gson. It uses a JSONObject and JSONArray approach.

import org.json.JSONObject;

String jsonString = "{\"name\":\"John\", \"age\":30}";

try {
    JSONObject jsonObject = new JSONObject(jsonString);
    String name = jsonObject.getString("name");
    int age = jsonObject.getInt("age");
    System.out.println(name);
} catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}

Parsing JSON Without Libraries:

You can technically parse JSON manually using Java's built-in string manipulation capabilities (e.g., String.substring(), regular expressions). However, this is strongly discouraged for anything beyond the simplest JSON structures.

String jsonString = "{\"name\":\"John\", \"age\":30}";

// Extremely simplified - doesn't handle escaping, complex structures, etc.
int nameStartIndex = jsonString.indexOf("\"name\":\"") + 7;
int nameEndIndex = jsonString.indexOf("\"", nameStartIndex);
String name = jsonString.substring(nameStartIndex, nameEndIndex);

System.out.println(name); // Output: John

Which library is the fastest and most performant ?

You can periodically visit this github repository for the latest benchmarks: https://github.com/fabienrenaud/java-json-benchmark

As of this writing "fastjson" is the winner!!!
